message_1: What is the specific activity of a radioactive sample which has an activity of 2.5 × 10^10 Bq and a mass of 100 g? (Assume the radioactive element has a half-life of 5.27 years and emits alpha particles.)
message_2:
The specific activity of a radioactive sample is defined as the activity per unit mass of the sample. In this case, we are given the activity (2.5 × 10^10 Bq) and the mass (100 g) of the sample.

To find the specific activity, simply divide the activity by the mass:

Specific activity = (Activity) / (Mass)
Specific activity = (2.5 × 10^10 Bq) / (100 g)

Specific activity = 2.5 × 10^8 Bq/g

So, the specific activity of the radioactive sample is 2.5 × 10^8 Bq/g.
